item.title: A Mind Is Born
item.description: Making a demo in just 256 bytes would be a formidable challenge regardless of platform. A Mind Is Born is my attempt to do it on the Commodore 64. In the absence of an actual 256-byte compo, it was submitted to the Oldskool 4K Intro compo at Revision 2017, where it ended up on 1st place.

item.title: C# 9 records as strongly-typed ids - Part 5: final bits and conclusion
item.description: We’re reaching the end of this series on records as strongly-typed ids. Sorry for the long delay since the last post… life happened! So far we’ve covered ASP.NET Core model binding, JSON serialization, and EF Core integration. Almost everything is working, we just need to fix a few more details. Handling database-generated values in EF Core First, I want to address a question asked by @OpsOwns in the comments of the last post:

item.title: Apple Silicon Tech Preview
Join our Cloud HD Video Meeting
item.description: Zoom is the leader in modern enterprise video communications, with an easy, reliable cloud platform for video and audio conferencing, chat, and webinars across mobile, desktop, and room systems. Zoom Rooms is the original software-based conference room solution used around the world in board, conference, huddle, and training rooms, as well as executive offices and classrooms. Founded in 2011, Zoom helps businesses and organizations bring their teams together in a frictionless environment to get more done. Zoom is a publicly traded company headquartered in San Jose, CA.

item.title: Words
item.description: Words that do not appear in the Agile Manifesto & Principles: Sprint backlog product owner manager PBI (product backlog item) scrum master Sprint review QA team PMO release train product increment stand-up (or Daily Scrum) meeting story point estimate velocity quarterly plan Jira productivity utilization certification standardized process (as a positive) methodology ceremony accountability responsibility hierarchy Jira :-) Words that do appear in the Agile Manifesto & Principles: individuals interaction valuable (software) collaboration change customer deliver…frequently conversation technical excellence simplicity self-organizing reflects on…effective adjusts And yes, I understand perfectly that the set of words that do not appear in the
item.author: (Allen Holub)

item.title: Creating other types of synchronization objects that can be used with co_await, part 9: The shared mutex (continued) | The Old New Thing
item.description: Last time, we tried to make an awaitable shared mutex, but ran into some problems. The first problem was that shared locks can starve out exclusive locks. To fix that, we say that you cannot steal the lock if there is already anybody waiting.

item.title: Third Time’s the Cache, No More
item.description: Up until now, we wouldn’t cache requests with query strings until we saw them three times. We trace that behavior back to 2010, examine why we might have needed it, and show ourselves why we don’t need it anymore.

item.title: How we found and fixed a rare race condition in our session handling - The GitHub Blog
item.description: On March 8, out of an abundance of caution, we logged all users out of GitHub.com. In this post we share technical details of the vulnerability and steps we're taking to ensure it doesn't happen again.

item.title: Who's the Best Engineer You've Worked With?
item.description: I ask this question in every interview I have with someone who has at least as much experience as I do. I ask this when I’m interviewing job candidates and also when I’m the one applying for a new position. I don’t really care about what that engineer’s name is or where they worked. I ask this question because it seems to be unheard of enough that most don’t have a canned response and it consistently spurs insightful conversation.

item.title: Relentlessly give the user what they want – Bryan Kennedy
item.description: I love my Peloton. Mostly it exists as a fancy piece of abstract art in my office, but I occasionally use it for workouts. When I overcome my lazy butt inertia, my experience is that the Peloton almost always wants to do an update.

item.title: MySQL from Below
item.description: When you insert data into a database and run COMMIT you expect things to be there: Atomically, Consistent, Isolated and Durable, like Codd commanded us 40 years ago, but also quickly. There is a surprising amount of sophistication being poured into this, but since I do not want to shame MongoDB and Redis developers in this post, I am not going to talk about that much in this place.

item.title: Almost Everything You Do Causes Almost Everything

item.description: Read manga online for free at MangaDex with no ads, high quality images and support scanlation groups!
item.author: (MangaDex)

item.title: Can we talk about client-side certificates?
item.description: I’m working on improving the means by which API users authenticate with the SourceHut API. Today, I was reading RFC 6749 (OAuth2) for this purpose, and it got me thinking about the original OAuth spec. I recalled vaguely that it had the API clients actually sign every request, and… yep, indeed it does. This also got me thinking: what else signs requests? TLS!

item.title: OpenTelemetry .NET reaches v1.0 | .NET Blog
item.description: As modern application environments are polyglot, distributed, and increasingly complex, observing your application to identify and react to failures has become challenging. In early 2019, two popular instrumentation projects, OpenTracing and OpenCensus, merged to create OpenTelemetry, a new standard for observability telemetry.
item.author: (Library Authors)
